026package org.jdrupes.mdoclet.internal.doclets.toolkit.taglets.snippet;
027
028import java.lang.ref.WeakReference;
029import java.util.ArrayList;
030import java.util.Collections;
031import java.util.HashMap;
032import java.util.HashSet;
033import java.util.List;
034import java.util.Map;
035import java.util.Objects;
036import java.util.Set;
037
038import static java.lang.Math.max;
039import static java.lang.Math.min;
040
041/**
042 * A mutable sequence of individually styleable characters.
043 */
044public class StyledText {
045
046    private Map<String, StyledText> bookmarks;
047    private StringBuilder chars;
048    private Styles styles;
049    private List<WeakReference<SubText>> subtexts;
050
051    public StyledText() {
052        init();
053    }
054
055    /*
056     * This method should be overridden to be no-op by a subclass that wants to
057     * inherit the interface but not the implementation, which includes
058     * unnecessary internal objects. If this is done, then all public methods
059     * should be overridden too, otherwise they will not work.
060     *
061     * An alternative design would be to provide an interface for styled text;
062     * but I ruled that out as unnecessarily heavyweight.
063     */
064    protected void init() {
065        this.bookmarks = new HashMap<>();
066        this.chars = new StringBuilder();
067        this.styles = new Styles();
068        this.subtexts = new ArrayList<>();
069    }
070
071    /*
072     * For each character of this text adds the provided styles to a set of
073     * styles associated with that character.
074     */
075    public void addStyle(Set<? extends Style> additionalStyles) {
076        styles.add(0, length(), additionalStyles);
077    }
078
079    public int length() {
080        return chars.length();
081    }
082
083    /*
084     * Replaces all characters of this text with the provided sequence of
085     * characters, each of which is associated with all the provided styles.
086     */
087    public void replace(Set<? extends Style> styles, CharSequence plaintext) {
088        replace(0, length(), styles, plaintext);
089    }
090
091    /*
092     * A multi-purpose operation that can be used to replace, insert or delete
093     * text. The effect on a text is as if [start, end) were deleted and
094     * then plaintext inserted at start.
095     */
096    private void replace(int start, int end, Set<? extends Style> styles,
097            CharSequence plaintext) {
098        chars.replace(start, end, plaintext.toString());
099        this.styles.delete(start, end);
100        this.styles.insert(start, plaintext.length(), styles);
101        // The number of subtexts is not expected to be big; hence no
102        // optimizations are applied
103        var iterator = subtexts.iterator();
104        while (iterator.hasNext()) {
105            WeakReference<SubText> ref = iterator.next();
106            SubText txt = ref.get();
107            if (txt == null) {
108                iterator.remove(); // a stale ref
109            } else {
110                update(start, end, plaintext.length(), txt);
111            }
112        }
113    }
114
115    /*
116     * Updates the text given the scope of the change to reflect text
117     * continuity.
118     */
119    private void update(int start, int end, int newLength, SubText text) {
120        assert start <= end;
121        assert text.start <= text.end;
122        assert newLength >= 0;
123        if (text.start == text.end && start == text.start) {
124            // insertion into empty text; special-cased for simplicity
125            text.end += newLength;
126            return;
127        }
128        if (end <= text.start) { // the change is on the left-hand side of the
129                                 // text
130            int diff = newLength - (end - start);
131            text.start += diff;
132            text.end += diff;
133        } else if (text.end <= start) { // the change is on the right-hand side
134                                        // of the text
135            // no-op; explicit "if" for clarity
136        } else { // the change intersects with the text
137            if (text.start <= start && end <= text.end) { // the change is
138                                                          // within the text
139                text.end += newLength - (end - start);
140            } else {
141                int intersectionLen
142                    = min(end, text.end) - max(start, text.start);
143                int oldLen = text.end - text.start;
144                if (start <= text.start) {
145                    text.start = start + newLength;
146                }
147                text.end = text.start + oldLen - intersectionLen;
148            }
149        }
150    }
151
152    private void addStyle(int start, int end,
153            Set<? extends Style> additionalStyles) {
154        styles.add(start, end, additionalStyles);
155    }
156
157    public StyledText getBookmarkedText(String bookmark) {
158        return bookmarks.get(Objects.requireNonNull(bookmark));
159    }
160
161    /*
162     * Maps the provided name to this text, using a flat namespace. A flat
163     * namespace means that this text (t), as well as any subtext derived from
164     * either t or t's subtext, share the naming map.
165     */
166    public void bookmark(String name) {
167        bookmark(name, 0, length());
168    }
169
170    private void bookmark(String name, int start, int end) {
171        bookmarks.put(Objects.requireNonNull(name), subText(start, end));
172    }
173
174    /*
175     * Selects a view of the portion of this text starting from start
176     * (inclusive) to end (exclusive).
177     *
178     * In contrast with java.util.List.subList, returned views provide extra
179     * consistency: they reflect structural changes happening to the underlying
180     * text and other views thereof.
181     */
182    public StyledText subText(int start, int end) {
183        Objects.checkFromToIndex(start, end, length());
184        var s = new SubText(start, end);
185        subtexts.add(new WeakReference<>(s));
186        return s;
187    }
188
189    /*
190     * Returns plaintext version of this text. This method is to be used for
191     * algorithms that accept String or CharSequence to map the result back to
192     * this text.
193     *
194     * There are no extensible "mutable string" interface. java.lang.Appendable
195     * does not support replacements and insertions. StringBuilder/StringBuffer
196     * is not extensible. Even if it were extensible, not many general-purpose
197     * string algorithms accept it.
198     */
199    public CharSequence asCharSequence() {
200        return chars;
201    }
202
203    /*
204     * Provides text to the consumer efficiently. The text always calls the
205     * consumer at least once; even if the text is empty.
206     */
207    public void consumeBy(StyledText.Consumer consumer) {
208        consumeBy(consumer, 0, length());
209    }
210
211    private void consumeBy(StyledText.Consumer consumer, int start, int end) {
212        Objects.checkFromToIndex(start, end, length());
213        styles.consumeBy(consumer, chars, start, end);
214    }
215
216    public StyledText append(Set<? extends Style> styles,
217            CharSequence sequence) {
218        subText(length(), length()).replace(styles, sequence);
219        return this;
220    }
221
222    public StyledText append(StyledText fragment) {
223        fragment.consumeBy((style, sequence) -> subText(length(), length())
224            .replace(style, sequence));
225        return this;
226    }
227
228    @FunctionalInterface
229    public interface Consumer {
230
231        void consume(Set<? extends Style> style, CharSequence sequence);
232    }
233
234    /*
235     * A structure that stores character styles.
236     */
237    private static final class Styles {
238
239        // Although this structure optimizes neither memory use nor object
240        // allocation, it is simple both to implement and reason about.
241
242        // list is a reference to ArrayList because this class accesses list by
243        // index, so this is important that the list is RandomAccess, which
244        // ArrayList is
245        private final ArrayList<Set<Style>> list = new ArrayList<>();
246
247        private void delete(int fromIndex, int toIndex) {
248            list.subList(fromIndex, toIndex).clear();
249        }
250
251        private void insert(int fromIndex, int length, Set<? extends Style> s) {
252            list.addAll(fromIndex, Collections.nCopies(length, Set.copyOf(s)));
253        }
254
255        private void add(int fromIndex, int toIndex,
256                Set<? extends Style> additional) {
257            Set<Style> copyOfAdditional = Set.copyOf(additional);
258            list.subList(fromIndex, toIndex)
259                .replaceAll(current -> sum(current, copyOfAdditional));
260        }
261
262        private Set<Style> sum(Set<? extends Style> a, Set<Style> b) {
263            // assumption: until there are complex texts, the most common
264            // scenario is the one where `a` is empty while `b` is not
265            if (a.isEmpty()) {
266                return b;
267            } else {
268                Set<Style> c = new HashSet<>(a);
269                c.addAll(b);
270                return Set.copyOf(c);
271            }
272        }
273
274        private void consumeBy(StyledText.Consumer consumer, CharSequence seq,
275                int start, int end) {
276            if (start == end) {
277                // an empty region doesn't have an associated set; special-cased
278                // for simplicity to avoid more complicated implementation of
279                // this method using a do-while loop
280                consumer.consume(Set.of(), "");
281            } else {
282                for (int i = start, j = i + 1; i < end; i = j) {
283                    var ith = list.get(i);
284                    while (j < end && ith.equals(list.get(j))) {
285                        j++;
286                    }
287                    consumer.consume(ith, seq.subSequence(i, j));
288                }
289            }
290        }
291    }
292
293    final class SubText extends StyledText {
294
295        int start, end;
296
297        private SubText(int start, int end) {
298            this.start = start;
299            this.end = end;
300        }
301
302        @Override
303        protected void init() {
304            // no-op
305        }
306
307        @Override
308        public void addStyle(Set<? extends Style> additionalStyles) {
309            StyledText.this.addStyle(start, end, additionalStyles);
310        }
311
312        @Override
313        public int length() {
314            return end - start;
315        }
316
317        @Override
318        public void replace(Set<? extends Style> styles,
319                CharSequence plaintext) {
320            // If the "replace" operation affects this text's size, which it
321            // can, then that size will be updated along with all other sizes
322            // during the bulk "update" operation in tracking text instance.
323            StyledText.this.replace(start, end, styles, plaintext);
324        }
325
326        @Override
327        public StyledText getBookmarkedText(String bookmark) {
328            return StyledText.this.getBookmarkedText(bookmark);
329        }
330
331        @Override
332        public void bookmark(String name) {
333            StyledText.this.bookmark(name, start, end);
334        }
335
336        @Override
337        public StyledText subText(int start, int end) {
338            return StyledText.this.subText(this.start + start,
339                this.start + end);
340        }
341
342        @Override
343        public CharSequence asCharSequence() {
344            return StyledText.this.asCharSequence().subSequence(start, end);
345        }
346
347        @Override
348        public void consumeBy(StyledText.Consumer consumer) {
349            StyledText.this.consumeBy(consumer, start, end);
350        }
351    }
352}
